Body:
BC-FRONTPAGE-NYT 
   (pr)  

   Here are the stories New York Times editors are planning for
Page 1, Thursday, Feb. 25. The N.Y. Times News Service Night
Supervisor is Pat Ryan; phone: (888) 346-9867; e-mail:
patryan(at)nytimes.com.

   TOP

   Lead story:

   MILITARY-PAY (Washington) _ In the GOP's first major
post-impeachment bill, the Senate votes overwhelmingly to give the
nation's military the biggest benefits increase since the early
1980s. By Eric Schmitt. (We plan to move the story by 9 p.m. ET in
``w'' news file.)

   Top center story:

   FOODSTAMPS (Undated) _ With a vibrant economy and tougher
regulations for public benefits, the nation's food stamp rolls have
dropped by a third in the past four years, from nearly 28 million
people to fewer than 19 million. By Andrew C. Revkin. (Scheduled to
move by 8:30 p.m. ET in ``a'' news file.)

   Off-lead:

   4-column reefer photo: AUSTRIA-AVALANCHE; story, map-graphic and
sidebar, AVALANCHE-CONTROL inside.

   FOLD

   EXCLUSIVE-CHINA-ENVOY (Washington) _ An accounting of the
Clinton White House's attempts to find an ambassador to China, a
task made difficult by deteriorating relations between Washington
and Beijing and by the weakened positon of the president. By
Elizabeth Becker. (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in ``a'' news
file.)

   BIOTECH-TREATY (Cartagena, Colombia) _ Attempts to forge the
world's first global treaty to regulate trade in genetically
modified products fails when the United States and five other big
agricultural exporters reject a proposal that had the support of
the rest of the roughly 130 nations. By Andrew Pollack. (The story
has moved in ``f'' news file.)

   reefer: KOSOVO-ASSESS and CLINTON; stories inside.

   BOTTOM

   NY-DOG-CONTROL (New York) _ Dog wars: a chronic conflict made
worse by a fashion among New Yorkers to own bigger, stronger, more
robust pets. As never before, big dogs are lunging out of
apartments to do what dogs must do. Tens of thousands of them are
dragging their owners (or paid walkers) to city parks. So to
preserve Central Park and especially Riverside Park, the city has
announced stiffer fines and increased enforcement. By getting tough
on free-range dogs _ an echo of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's
``quality-of-life'' crackdown _ the city hopes to convince dog
owners that it is unhealthful and even shameful to let dogs run
free. ``You might call them dog terrorists,'' the parks
commissioner said. By Blaine Harden. (Scheduled to move by 8:30
p.m. ET in ``a'' news file.) Story runs under 3-column photo.

   EXCLUSIVE-UNKNOWN-SOLDIERS (Washington) _ Exploring the impact
that modern forensic science has on the military's ability to
identify war dead. By Steven Lee Myers. (We will move this story at
8:30 ET in the ``w'' news file.) With photo.

   INSIDE STORIES PROMOTED ON PAGE 1:

   MEXICO-DRUGS (Washington) _ The head of the Drug Enforcement
Administration, Thomas A. Constantine, warned today that Mexican
drug trafficking organizations pose the worst criminal threat to
the United States that he has seen in nearly four decades in law
enforcement. By Christopher S. Wren. (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m.
ET in ``i'' news file.)

   GRAMMYS (Los Angeles) _ Lauryn Hill led the parade of women up
for awards at the Grammys on Wednesday night, with 10 nominations.
(Scheduled to move by 10 p.m. ET in ``e'' news file.)
